ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Further knowledge of the Spanish language, both grammatical and cultural
I furthered my studies in Spanish, and particularly developed my knowledge of Spanish cultural literature.
A better grasp of Spanish, especially in written and conversational forms.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The Spanish department makes an A too hard to get!
The professor was wonderful, but consistently went over class time by about 10 minutes

I think the strengths lie in the professor's teaching ability. Concepts were well explained and paired with group discussions that further the understanding of the material. Weaknesses are few but may include excessively long homework assignments.

The brisk pace of this course can be strenuous at times, but if you keep up, the assessments will be manageable.  In other words, the course is a lot of work, but it really is organized in an effective manner.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Synchronous learning only three days a week was a fantastic improvement that helped leaven stress, yet keep delivering the same amount of material
I felt very engaged with the course, despite the online learning. I think the small class size along with frequent use of breakout rooms contributed to reinforcing my understanding.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend the course to anyone looking to fulfill a language requirement

I would recommend this course to another student. I greatly enjoyed the inclusion of cultural learning within the actual grammar learning topics. The inclusion of activities such as short readings, movies, and literature all helped to increase engagement with the course as well as bolster my understanding of the material.
Yes! If you want to getting more comfortable with Spanish, this is the way to go.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Course was asynchronous two days a week, with live discussion and learning three days a week
Online notes/powerpoints, assigned readings, daily exercises
